ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I learned how to write a conclusion
I learned how to properly analyze poetry
I learned how to close read novels
I learned how to make my writing flow better
Developed essay writing skills, ability to discuss complex topics, and analyze different literary works.
I definitely improved as a writer, and also wrote more confidently. I learned a lot about queer history and got to read many wonderful works that have stuck with me to the end of the semester.

I learned about the complex ways sexuality reflects power dynamics based on the intersection of race, class, gender, disability, etc. I also became a better writer through four different writing assignments; these challenged us to synthesize texts, draw meanings from the author's words, think creatively, and capture our own voice.

I learned how to read diverse works of literature more critically and analyze themes of power, identity, sexuality, and expression. I also learned how to synthesize that process with real-world information and research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The books that you read in this class are really fun to read
Michael is a really fun instructor, he makes the class engaging
Strengths: Class was almost always engaging and really enjoyed the readings and assignments.

Virtual lecture definitely made things challenging, but Professor Abraham-Fiallos is amazing and persevered through all of the technical difficulties and internet issues, and guided our conversation in really interesting directions.

Strengths of the course were the texts and the professor. Based on these two things, us students were able to engage in conversation really well and create an environment where we were all building off of one another's ideas. Professor was also really understanding with extensions regarding outside circumstances. Overall, I really enjoyed this course. No true weaknesses to this class except for occasional zoom fatigue.

I really enjoyed this class overall. The discussions were interesting and engaged, the course content was well-chosen, and the professor was always incredibly supportive. He found a balance between pushing us to become better students while also giving us the guidance we needed to succeed. We discussed this in class, but the only thing Id say is that Coldness and Cruelty was very difficult to get through.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think that as far as discussion classes go during covid, this one was very successful
Wish it were in person (as we only had 7 students) but class was still very interesting over Zoom.
I think that discussion posts were a lot less engaging and difficult to maintain, but the virtual discussion in the live classes were really great!

Discussion was successful as students would raise hand and professor would call on them. Sometimes internet connection was poor. Do wish we shared screen more when looking at texts instead of having to pull it up yourself.

This was one of the classes that I felt was least hindered by the virtual setting. I thought that the small class environment and engaged discussion-based setting allowed me to get a lot out of the class, despite it being online.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this class to another student. I think that everyone should learn a little bit more about sexuality and how it plays into power dynamics.
Yes! 100% everyone should take this class.

Of course! Definitely take this class with Professor Abraham-Fiallos. You will learn a lot, get to read a lot of interesting and provocative literature, and learn how to sit in the discomfort of certain topics while still maintaining a dialogue/conversation about them. A lovely class taught by a lovely professor, and an amazing reading list.

Yes! This was my probably favorite class I've taken at Yale so far. Michael was great and I really enjoyed the discussions we had in class. I also enjoyed looking at a wide range of literature and art including novels, poetry, plays, film, photography, collage, etc. The reading list for this course is also great!
Yes, I would definitely recommend this course. Professor Abraham is very nice and facilitates a nice discussion.
Yes, I would definitely recommend this class to someone as long as they are willing to step out of their comfort zone and are open to discussing topics that can feel a bit uncomfortable or taboo.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Office hours
Virtual seminar.
